Monday, July 12, 2021

This was written as part of Vine & Figâ€™s Sunday Scripture reflection project.

When Jesus sent out his Twelve, He told them: â€œWhatever place does not welcome you or listen to you, leave there and shake the dust off your feet in testimony against them.â€ If youâ€™re not welcomed, not listened to, quietly withdraw. Donâ€™t make a scene. Shrug your shoulders and be on your way.

Last week, a friend of ours in the Vine & Fig community asked me to proofread a letter. It was addressed to her parents, and it asked, in the calm voice of a young woman embracing adulthood, whether or not she and her female partner could count on the same respect, dignity, and love that she saw flow from her parents to her siblings and their partners. Our friend and her partner had just moved in together, and things had gotten serious enough that an introduction was in order, even for her huge anti-queer Catholic family.

The letter asked, and it did not barter.

â€œOh, this is not the first draft,â€ she tells me after I compliment her vulnerability and bravery, â€œthe first one was me basically begging to be loved.â€ From where Iâ€™m sitting, I can see that this isnâ€™t the first time our friend has had to beg. Her father and mother never seemed to have gotten this whole queer thing. Theyâ€™ve been waiting for â€œthis phaseâ€ to end for years. In their household, there is simply no â€œlove for the gaysâ€. It took a conversation with our friendâ€™s future mother-in-law to make her look at her parents with her eyes open a little wider.

â€œYou donâ€™t need your parents as much as you think you doâ€ the woman had said.

I imagine our friend crawling out from under the rubble left by the type of guilt only a Catholic parent can channel. I imagine the many lives in our community, with varying degrees of urgency, transforming as we come to understand the difference between a hurt that grows from love and one that grows from neglect.

I imagine all of us building a home, knocking on doors to see who will help us share love the way we see it, and learning to shake the dust off our boots and moving right along, even if it requires making a whole family from scratch.

Saturday, July 10, 2021

Her Summer break started yesterday, and as always it is an event. I am so excited about getting everything right that I mostly present as a frantic killjoy. Jeopardy makes everything better.

I start today with my usual bike route past the bakeries. Niemeijer for pain au choc and canelÃ©s, followed by tiger buns and krentenbollen at Simon Meijssen. Niemeijer won best croissant of Amsterdam, but I think theyâ€™re too bready.

In the window of Meijssen theyâ€™re showcasing pride muffins. Neither of us likes muffins, but I buy two anyway. Theyâ€™re surprisingly good.

Thursday, July 1, 2021

The other day, as I was speaking about a group of queer Black designers of which Iâ€™m a part, a White lesbian asked me: â€œwhen does a group exist just so a bunch of outcasts can commiserate about their shared otherness? I mean, could someone like me join?â€

â€œGreat questions,â€ I said, â€œmy response is identical to what you would say if someone went â€˜why do you need lesbian bars? You donâ€™t see me going to a straight bar, do you?â€™â€

â€œFair enoughâ€ said the White lesbian.

I found an app called Liberate. It has beautiful meditations by Black and Indigenous teachers. Iâ€™ve always been a Headspace fan. Despite founder Andyâ€™s cringey â€œI lived with the monks so you didnâ€™t have toâ€ marketing strategy, I appreciate the app for its interface and quality content. It hadnâ€™t occured to me that the experiences I have as an Afropean could find their place in a meditation practice.

Part of me feels too indulgent for enjoying Liberate as much as I do. Listening to meditation teachers who have the understanding that microagressions are an actual reality in my actual life is just so different and amazing. Still, my subconscious feels sorry for the theoretical White people who would be uncomfortable if they found out I listen to Black meditations. Why even bring your identity into it?! Like a lesbian momentarily forgetting sheâ€™s allowed her lesbian bar.

Saturday, June 26, 2021

The weather is great, infection rates are down, and the Dutch government loosened Covid restrictions. Masks are no longer required in public indoor spaces. Iâ€™m at Basquiat waiting to catch up with a friend, and an Irish woman strikes up a conversation.

â€œI like to sit here late in the afternoon to watch the sun set between the buildings. I canâ€™t take much sun, I have Irish skin, you know.â€

She sneezes, and I remark how, since March 2020, â€œgesundheitâ€ has been replaced by dirty looks. â€œI need my allergy medsâ€ she says, in her voice a hint of embarrassment. Then she tells me about her successes of late: she and the old English Bulldog next to her have finally begun frequenting the neighborhood bars again, the ones â€œwhere everyone recognizes themâ€. Sheâ€™s also been making lots of new friends. She suspects itâ€™s the sign sheâ€™s been sporting on her mobility scooter, which reads if I die because of Covid, itâ€™s not your fault.

â€œI feel so sorry for all the young people, you know? One of them told me they were scared to go out and party, fearing their reckless behavior would kill their grandparents. You know what I told him? I told him it wasnâ€™t his fault. And you know what? He fell into my arms crying.â€

Apparently, she hasnâ€™t missed a single Sunday protest on Museum Square.

â€œItâ€™s really insane, the weaponry and violence that are on standby on Sundays. Iâ€™m from Belfast, you know, so you could say Iâ€™ve been around the block a few times. Even in Belfast, during our protests, they only pulled out weapons when things got really tough. Here, it seems thatâ€™s their only strategy. And Iâ€™m from Belfast, go figure.â€

In the evening, Anja and I go to Dignita Hoftuin, where our friends plan to announce their elopement in Kopenhagen earlier this week. Upon arrival, before Iâ€™ve been able to discern whether Iâ€™d like to consent to anything, I receive a warm hug from my friend, and a handshake from a total stranger.

What makes the pandemic such a fickle game is that nobody looks like theyâ€™re infected. Everyone who breaches my personal space looks kind. Still, the Delta variant is coming for us, and Iâ€™m surprised by how much my conservatism sticks out like a sore thumb everywhere I go.
